data.text: Contents

Approval and Implementation ................................................................................... 8 10 References .................................................................................................................. 8 11 Equality Impact Assessment ..................................................................................... 8 Appendix 1: Children's Early Warning Tool Observation chart 0-12 months………....9 Appendix 2: Paediatric Neurological Observation chart Under 5 years………….…..10 Appendix 3: Head Injury Advice Sheet for Under  years old…………………………11 Appendix 4 Equality Impact Assessment…………………………………………………..14
Babies Accidentally Dropped 10days to  months old / 19016/1.0
Page  of
Introduction

A recent patient safety alert issued by NHS Improvement highlighted the risks of accidentally dropping a baby/infant whilst an inpatient in hospital. The National Reporting and Learning System found during a 12 month period that 182 babies had been dropped in obstetric and midwifery settings and 66 babies accidentally dropped whilst in paediatric wards. All of these incidents occurred when the baby was in the care of parents or visiting members of family
Scope

This Policy is for babies and infants from 10 days up to 1 year of age who as patients have been accidentally dropped whilst in the hospital. This is not for babies/ infants dropped at home or whilst they are visiting hospitals. In these cases they should follow the normal processes of accessing the Emergency Department if necessary.
Definitions
Roles and Responsibilities
Chief Executive has overall responsibility and accountability for ensuring safe and effective systems are in place to care for babies and infants whilst inpatients.
The Director of Patient Safety is responsible for ensuring that resources and mechanisms are in place for the implementation , monitoring and review of this guideline
Lead Consultant for Paediatrics is responsible for ensuring that policies and procedures relating to the assessment and management of babies accidentally dropped whilst an inpatient are available.
The Paediatric Team

The On-call Paediatric Consultant paediatrician will be responsible for the care of the baby/infant following a fall whilst an inpatient irrespective of which specialty the baby is admitted under whilst in the ward.

The Ward Manager has overall responsibility for the safety of the patients whilst in the ward. They will be responsible for ensuring risk assessments are carried out and up to date especially in relation to the use of cot sides to reduce the risk of falls.
After Initial Incident

Babies and infants who are accidentally dropped or fall whilst in hospital should be assessed straight away. Babies who are clinically unstable following the fall should be assessed and treated immediately calling the Paediatric on call team to request their immediate assistance. Call the Paediatric Cardiac Arrest Team if necessary on 2222 and follow the care pathways for a critically ill child (refer to Critically ill Child16025)
If the baby is stable then the nurse should perform a set of routine observations, these should include:
Pulse, Temperature, Respiratory Rate, Blood Pressure and Oxygen Saturations charted on an age appropriate Observation chart and CEWT score calculated. (Refer to Appendix 1)
Full set of Neurological Observations. Pupil reactions and motor skills assessment using the correct age appropriate chart and a GCS score calculated.
(Refer to Appendix 2)

The on-call Paediatric Registrar should be informed of the incident as soon as possible and the paediatricians need to make a full clinical assessment of the baby including a neurological assessment and taking into account the history regarding the fall.
Full history and subsequent documentation of the incident should be made in the patient's notes. The history should include:
Who was looking after the baby at the time of the incident;
If the Baby was being held at the time of the fall, who was holding the baby;
Time of fall;
Time of reporting the incidence;
The position in which the baby fell;
An estimated height of the fall and the type of surface they landed on;
The circumstances surrounding the fall;
Whether the baby cried immediately after the fall;
Any witnesses to the incident;
And the last time the baby was seen prior to the fall.
The Paediatrician should document within the baby's medical notes the baby's neurological examination and if there are any marks or bruises visible (ideally this should be documented on a body map).
The Paediatric Consultant should be informed of the incident to ensure an appropriate care plan is in place and to consider any further treatment or investigations necessary.

A clear plan should be documented in the notes and discussed with the nurse looking after the baby as well as the nurse in charge with a plan for Neurological observations frequency and duration, and if there is a need for x-ray or CT scan at the initial time of accident.

Guidance from the NICE guidelines of children following a head injury should be sought  https://www.nice.org.uk/guidance/cg176. Recommended frequency of neurological observations can be found in the NICE guidance.
The incident should be reported via the Trust's DATIX system.
Safeguarding checks should be carried out using the online access to GP and Health Visitors records as well as discussing with the Safeguarding Children's team.

The nursing staff should monitor the baby/ infant according to the plan requested by the Paediatric Team. Any concerns regarding the condition of the baby/infant should be reported immediately to the Paediatric team and documented in the notes.

The Paediatric team should respond to any concerns promptly when there is altered neurological behaviour, or any other deviation from the patients normal parameters. This change in status may alter the previous plan provided and referral to the NICE guidelines for Head Injury in Children should made.

After a period of observation as requested by the Paediatric Team, prior to discharge if the observations are all within normal parameters a final examination of the baby/ infant should be done – preferably by the Senior Clinician who assessed the baby after initial incident.
The incident should be documented in the baby/ infant's GP discharge letter and in their Parent held record (Red Book)

Advice should be given to the parents about head injury and the signs and symptoms to look out for on discharge. These ‘Red Flags' are highlighted in the Head Injury Advice Sheet for under 5 year olds and should be given to the parents prior to discharge. (See Appendix 3)
Prevention of Falls
All babies and infants when left in their cots should have their cot sides raised to the appropriate level to prevent them from falling out.
Any baby or infant if left on their own however short a time should be placed in their cot with the sides up.

The nurse looking after the baby or infant is responsible for ensuring their safety whilst an inpatient. They should inform the parents and their visitors how to operate the cot sides. A risk assessment on admission for cot sides should be completed and documented on the Manual Handling form in the admission paperwork. The parent/carer is responsible for their child's safety whilst in their care.
Co sleeping in the parents' beds is not recommended on the ward and there are notices around the ward to notify parents and visitors that children are not allowed on the parents beds.
All cots are maintained and serviced by BME. Any cots found not to be in full working order should be reported to BME for repair by phoning them on Ext
All new staff, Bank and Agency staff should be shown on induction to the ward how to operate the cot sides.
Training Requirements
All nursing staff working on the ward will be shown how to use the equipment including the cot sides.
All staff must attend manual handling mandatory training which includes the use of the beds on the ward.
Monitoring and Audit
Each document must outline the Trust's process of monitoring compliance with, and the effectiveness of the document's main points.

data.text: Approval and Implementation
Approved guidelines are published monthly in the Trust's staff newsletter that is sent via email to all staff.
Equality Impact Assessment
Mid Essex Hospital Services NHS Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals. (Refer to Appendix 4)
References
NICE Guidelines https://www.nice.org.uk/guidance/cg176
Assessment and Management of babies who are accidentally dropped in hospital https://improvement.nhs.uk/documents/5309/Patient_Safety_Alert_- Management_of_babies_accidentally_dropped_in_hospital.pdf
Nottingham University Hospital. Baby Falls Management and Prevention Guideline. https://www.nuh.nhs.uk/download.cfm?doc=docm93jijm4n979.pdf&ver=2661

A change to an existing policy
A change to the way staff work
What are you proposing to change?
No change proposed but a guideline to support the current practice
Why are you making this change? (What will the change achieve?)
Following a National Patient Safety Alert. Guideline for Accidentally dropped babies was required
Who benefits from this change and how?
All babies as inpatients on the paediatric ward
